key_points: Hurricane Ida destroyed a historic building in New Orleans that was significant to jazz history and Louis Armstrong.
The building, located downtown on South Rampart Street, was near the French Quarter.
Originally, the building housed the Karnofsky Tailor Shop, important in the early life of Louis Armstrong.
The Karnofsky family, Jewish immigrants, significantly influenced Armstrong, even giving him his first instrument.
Louis Armstrong worked for the Karnofsky family and received their support in his early musical career.
The Karnofskys loaned Armstrong money to buy his first cornet, under the condition that he works for them for another year.
Morris Karnofsky, one of Armstrong's boyhood friends, later opened the city's first jazz record store, which Armstrong frequented.
Louis Armstrong became a jazz and popular music icon, known for his trumpet playing and singing.
Efforts to restore the building as a city landmark have failed to materialize.
A real estate firm had plans to restore the building as a homage to jazz history, but it is now destroyed.
